bestBHT.bht: May the grace of the Lord Jesus be with the saints, a fitting benediction that concludes this apocalyptic book, meant to be read in the churches. It is a good word for the close of this marvelous picture of God's gracious provision for his people on earth and in heaven. Let a sense of the love of Christ abide upon you, as you see your interest in the redeeming grace of Christ and trust in its fullness. May the free love of the Lord Jesus and all its fruits be with all who long for his appearing.

Henry Alford: The grace of the Lord Jesus be with the saints (i. e, with the church of God. This, the reading of the Sinaitic MS., is nowhere else found as a parting formula).
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: This closing benediction, Paul's mark in his Epistles, was after Paul's death taken up by John.
The Old Testament ended with a 'curse' in connection with the law; the New Testament ends with a blessing in union with the Lord Jesus.

May the Blessed Lord who has caused all holy Scriptures to be written for our learning, bless this humble effort to make Scripture expound itself, and make it an instrument towards the conversion of sinners and the edification of saints, to the glory of His great name and the hastening of His kingdom! Amen.
Albert Barnes: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen - The usual benediction of the sacred writers. See the notes on Romans 16:20.
Marvin Vincent: With you all [μετα παντων υμων] . The readings differ. Some read meta pantwn with all, omitting you. Others, meta twn aJgiwn with the saints.
Archibald T. Robertson: The grace of the Lord Jesus be with the saints.
an unusual ending for an apocalypse, but suitable for one meant to be read in the churches.
It is a good word for the close of this marvellous picture of God's gracious provision for his people in earth and heaven.
John Gill: Let a sense of the love of Christ...abide upon you.
May you see your interest in the redeeming grace of Christ, in all its branches.
Let the fulness of grace in Christ be the object of your trust and confidence.
John Wesley: Of the Lord Jesus — And all its fruits.
Be with all — Who thus long for his appearing!

bhtAttempts.bht: May the grace of the Lord Jesus be with the saints, a fitting benediction that concludes this apocalyptic book, meant to be read in the churches. It is a good word for the close of this marvelous picture of God's gracious provision for his people on earth and in heaven. Let a sense of the love of Christ abide upon you, as you see your interest in the redeeming grace of Christ and trust in its fullness. May the free love of the Lord Jesus and all its fruits be with all who long for his appearing.

May the grace of the Lord Jesus be with the saints, a closing benediction taken up by John after Paul's death. This unusual ending for an apocalypse is suitable for a book meant to be read in the churches, as it highlights God's gracious provision for his people on earth and in heaven. Let a sense of the love of Christ abide upon you and trust in the redeeming grace of Christ and its fullness. May the free love of the Lord Jesus and all its fruits be with all who long for his appearing.

May the grace of the Lord Jesus be with the saints, a fitting and unusual ending for this apocalyptic book. It is a good word for the close of this marvelous picture of God's provision. Let a sense of the love of Christ abide upon you and see your interest in the redeeming grace and trust in its fullness. May the free love of the Lord Jesus and all its fruits be with all who long for his appearing. Amen.

May the grace of the Lord Jesus be with the saints, a benediction that marks the conclusion of this apocalyptic book. It is an unusual ending, but appropriate for a book meant to be read in the churches. This closing blessing highlights God's gracious provision for his people on earth and in heaven. May the love of Christ abide in you and may you trust in the redeeming grace he offers. May the free love of the Lord Jesus and all its fruits be with all who eagerly anticipate his return.

May the grace of the Lord Jesus be with the saints, a benediction that concludes this apocalyptic book. It is a fitting ending, highlighting God's gracious provision for his people on earth and in heaven. Let the love of Christ abide in you and trust in the redeeming grace he offers. May the free love of the Lord Jesus and all its fruits be with all who long for his appearing.
